dublinCore.dc:title: 119 HR 986 IH: Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Establishment Act Amendments Act of 2025
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Ms. Balint introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Natural Resources

form.official-title: To amend the Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Establishment Act to expand the boundary of the Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park in the State of Vermont, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Establishment Act Amendments Act of 2025.
Section 3 of the Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Establishment Act (16 U.S.C. 410vv–1) is amended by striking subsection (b) and inserting the following:

subparagraph.text: The boundaries of the park shall be as generally depicted on the map entitled Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park, Proposed Boundary Revision, numbered 456/190,048, and dated August 2023.
The park shall include the following:

subclause.text: a portion of the area known as Mt. Tom.

clause.text: A protection zone, including the area occupied by the Billings Farm and Museum.
The King Farm, which shall be divided between the historic zone described in clause (i) and the protection zone described in clause (ii), as determined by the Secretary to be appropriate.

paragraph.text: The map described in paragraph (1)(A) shall be on file and available for public inspection in the appropriate offices of the National Park Service.

section.text: Section 4 of the Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Establishment Act (16 U.S.C. 410vv–2) is amended—

subparagraph.text: by striking paragraphs (1) and (2) and inserting the following:

paragraph.text: The Secretary may acquire land or an interest in land within the boundary of the park by—

subparagraph.text: purchase from a willing seller with donated or appropriated funds;
transfer from a Federal agency; or

paragraph.text: Acquisition by the Secretary of the land described in section 3(b)(1)(B)(iii) shall include—

subparagraph.text: a right of access from the land acquired to the park; and
a right of access to the land acquired from the park.
in paragraph (3), by striking (3) The Secretary and inserting the following:

paragraph.text: by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: On acquisition by the Secretary of the land described in section 3(b)(1)(B)(iii), the acquired land may be used for—

paragraph.text: agricultural and forestry purposes, including the growing and harvesting of crops and trees, animal husbandry, and other agricultural operations customary in the State of Vermont;
conservation purposes in a manner that preserves the historic character of a working farm and forest; and
educational purposes relating to agriculture, forestry, and conservation activities, including the study of natural history.

section.text: Section 5(a) of the Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Establishment Act (16 U.S.C. 410vv–3(a)) is amended by striking Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Scenic Zone Map and dated November 19, 1991 and inserting Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park, Proposed Boundary Revision, numbered 456/190,048, and dated August 2023.
The Marsh-Billings-Rockefeller National Historical Park Establishment Act (16 U.S.C. 410vv et seq.) is amended—

paragraph.text: by redesignating sections 6 through 10 as sections 7 through 11, respectively; and
by inserting after section 5 the following:

subsection.text: There is established at the park the National Park Service Stewardship Institute (referred to in this Act as the Institute).
The purposes of the Institute are—

paragraph.text: to highlight and encourage the advancement of stewardship practices through workshops, public programs, learning opportunities, and similar programming;
to create opportunities within the National Park Service to identify and share innovation through research, evaluation, and dialogue; and
to identify and exchange best practices and enhance leadership capacity, partnership development, and community engagement in the fields of conservation and resource stewardship.

subsection.text: The Institute shall be managed as a program of the park.
